parts: Name this American policy during World War Two which confined members of certain ethnic group to various relocation camps.
Japanese internment was unsuccessfully challenged in this 1944 court case. In a 6-3 decision, the Supreme Court ruled that the need for national security trumped the plaintiff’s individual rights.
This term describes second generation Japanese Americans, including Fred Korematsu. Despite the injustice of internment, many members of this group served in the U.S. military.
Name this warrior figure of Celtic mythology who lead the Fianna after ousting the traitor Goll Mac Morna.
Finn Mac Cumaill is the hero of this cycle of Irish mythology, often compared to the Ulster, Invasions, and Historical cycles.
This man is the primary narrator of the Fenian Cycle. This son of Finn Mac Cumaill fell off of his horse while on his way to visit his father, trapping him outside of the Land of Youth forever.
Name these four-dimensional numbers that take the form a+bi+cj+dk that, unlike the complex numbers, lack the commutative property.

Quaternions were introduced by this Irish mathematician in 1843. With Arthur Cayley, he names a theorem stating that every square matrix over a commutative ring satisfies its own characteristic equation.
When the equation that i-squared, j-squared, k-squared, and ijk equals negative one occurred to Hamilton, he could not resist carving it on one of these structures.

answers: Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon
parts: Name this 700 year period in which Christian forces gradually reclaimed the Iberian peninsula from Muslim kingdoms.
These two Catholic monarchs completed Reconquista in 1492 after conquering Granada. That same year, the duo funded an expedition led by Christopher Columbus.
This final Muslim ruler in Spain attempted to live out his days peacefully, but like many Spanish Muslims, oppressive Christian rule led him to emigrate.

answers: laser (accept light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation)
gain medium (accept gain media, active laser media, or lasing media)
parts: Name this state of a system that has higher energy than a ground state.
More members of a system are in excited states when population inversion occurs, which is necessary in these devices. Theodore Maiman built one of these devices using a ruby crystal.
This type of material has quantum properties that allow it to amplify laser beams. It is excited by a pump source.
Name this North African country whose capital city is Rabat.
Morocco was home to this powerful medieval dynasty, based in Marrakesh and with dominions extending from Spain to Mauretania.
Since 1975, the Moroccan Army has sporadically battled the Polisario Front for control of this disputed desert region along the Atlantic coast.
Name this extensive work about the life of the son of Emperor Kiritsubo as he rises and falls through the ranks of court and womanizes incessantly.
This lady-in-waiting wrote The Tale of Genji.
This is the name of Genji’s first love. He later trains one of her relatives, a girl named Murasaki, to be exactly like her.

answers: atomic orbitals (prompt on “electron orbital” and “orbital,” do not accept “molecular orbital” or “shell”)
parts: Name these entities that can contain a maximum of two electrons.
The mixing of atomic orbitals leads to hybridization into hybrid orbitals with different energies. Methane has this hybridization because it is tetrahedral and has formula CH4.

Molecular orbital theory can also be used to determine molecular structures. In MO theory, this quantity is defined as the number of bonding electrons minus the number of antibonding electrons divided by 2.
Name this book of the Bible in which a wise teacher ponders the meaning of life.

In one of Ecclesiastes most notable sections, the Teacher asserts that there is one of these concepts for “every purpose under heaven,” including one to be born, one to die, one to weep, and one to laugh.
This thinker cited Ecclesiastes’ claim that the “number of fools is infinite” when discussing the quantity of good and evil in his Summa Theologica.
Name this southern belle who marries a wealthy blockade runner and manages Tara Plantation.
This is the novel that Scarlett appears in, a Margaret Mitchell novel set during and after the American Civil War.
In Gone with the Wind, Melanie explains that Scarlett’s husbands are all a part of this group, whose activities lead to the death of Frank Kennedy.
The trail begins at Mount Katahdin in this New England state which also contains Acadia National Park.
The Appalachian Trail passes through these mountains named for their coloration when viewed from a distance. A parkway through these mountains is the most visited part of the National Park Service.
The Great Smoky Mountains, a subrange of the Blue Ridge, contain this peak, the highest point on the Appalachian Trail.
Name this former Director of the FBI and Special Counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
In October 2017, Mueller’s team indicted this man on charges of money laundering. This lobbyist is accused of masking millions of dollars in payments from the Ukrainian government.
This man serves as the White House’s lead attorney in matters relating to Mueller’s investigation. This man shares his name with a former Detroit Tigers second baseman.
This Middle Eastern nation has endured a bloody civil war since 2011, pitting dictator Bashar al-Assad, resistance fighters, ISIS, and the Kurdish Rojava against each other.

This Middle Eastern country is also embroiled in civil war, with former President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi and his Saudi allies clashing with former President Ali Abdullah Saleh and his Iran-backed Houthi allies.
Though long running civil war in Sri Lanka ended in 2009, tensions remain between the Sri Lankan government and this ethnic group whose “Liberation Tigers” were defeated in the brutal conflict.

answers: A Journal of the Plague Year
parts: This Thomas Mann novella follows the ascetic Gustav von Aschenbach’s infatuation with Tadzio in a cholera-ridden Italian city.
This novel by Albert Camus takes place in the French-Algerian city of Oran and features characters like Cottard and Dr. Castel.
Daniel Defoe recounted a disease stricken London in this novel, which he published under a pseudonym to hide his age when the outbreak actually occurred.
This character in Pygmalion learns elocution from Professor Henry Higgins, eventually passing off as a high society lady.
This location is where Eliza works as a Cockney flower girl and meets the professor.
Pygmalion was adapted into this long-running Lerner and Loewe musical. Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews starred in this show’s original run.
Name this 1907 Pablo Picasso painting depicting five prostitutes in a brothel.
Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is set in this Spanish city whose Museu Picasso maintains the largest collection of Picasso works in the world.
Les Demoiselles d'Avignon was partially inspired by this El Greco painting which shows St. John with outstretched arms looking a several nude people.
Name this work commemorating the defense of Russia from Napoleon’s invading Grand Armee, complete with cannon fire.
This composer of The Nutcracker and Swan Lake also wrote the 1812 Overture.
This term describes an A-flat phrase in Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. 4. This terms also refers to a section that opens Shostakovich’s 8th Symphony.

answers: a good person (or good man, or descriptive equivalents)
parts: Name this diary of personal reflections and self-improvement compiled by the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius. This text urges its reader not to “act as if you were going to live ten thousand years.”
In Meditations, Marcus discourages the discussion of what makes up this concept and instead urges the reader to just be one.
Meditations aligns with this school of philosophy founded by Zeno and known for its foundational logic and dismissal of emotions. The works of Seneca the Younger also express this philosophy.
Name this sculptor of The Resting Satyr and The Aberdeen Head.
This sculpture by Praxiteles features a Greek god balancing a small baby in his hand. The arm missing from this sculpture was likely holding grapes.
Praxiteles created multiple sculptures of this God, including Lycian and Sauroktonos versions. Depictions of this god often show him playing a lute or slaying Python.

answers: CRISPR (accept clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats)
parts: Name this procedure used to amplify segments of DNA.
This is another biological technique using DNA. It is a genome editing technology adapted from a prokaryotic defense system.
The CRISPR immunity system in Streptococcus pyogenes is related to this protein. It is used to create a double stranded break in foreign DNA.
Name this suite by Camille Saint-Saens that includes movements such as Fossils, and Kangaroos.
This movement of The Carnival of the Animals uses a very slow version of the “Galop Infernal,” often called the Can-Can.
This ballet was choreographed by Mikhail Fokine on the movement “Le Cygne.” It was performed by Anna Pavlova 4,000 times.
